Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Data-driven Robust Approach for Large Scale Dynamic Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to develop data-driven tractable and robust approach for large-scale dynamic optimization under uncertainty. This is a fundamental problem especially in today's world of BigData where we want to efficiently use vast amount of available data for decision-making. Due to its wide applicability, any progress in this field will have significant impact in practice. This project will address two fundamental problems in dynamic optimization. The first is related to modeling the underlying uncertainties in the optimization problem from data. Traditionally, probability theory has been used to model these uncertainties but it is often computationally intractable especially in high dimensions suffering from the curse of dimensionality. This research will develop new data-driven paradigms to model uncertainty that simultaneously ensure tractability and good performance. The second problem concerns developing efficient and robust algorithms for resulting multi-period optimization problems. The goal is to pursue the development and analysis of robust, practical and easy to implement algorithms through simple functional policy approximations with potentially strong theoretical performance guarantees.

If successful, the results of this research will develop foundational theory for tractable dynamic optimization and provide fundamental and practical new tools for a broad spectrum of real world problems. These results will be used to develop practical solutions for optimization problems arising in electricity markets and smart grid applications, which is an important area where dynamic optimization is very applicable. The graduate and undergraduate students will benefit from involvement in research and integration of the results into classroom instruction. The research will be broadly disseminated through outreach programs to local high schools with a goal of increasing the participation of students especially from underrepresented minorities in STEM education and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamic optimization refers to the broad class of sequential decision problems in face of uncertain problem parameters. Everyone including individuals, businesses and even Governments need to ?solve? such decision problems at a regular basis. The two fundamental challenges in such problems include: i) designing a tractable model to capture the uncertainty in the problem, and ii) to efficiently solve the resulting dynamic optimization problem. The broad goal of this project was to develop a tractable data-driven robust approach for solving dynamic optimization problems where the focus is on three broad objectives: i) develop a data-driven approach to model uncertainty including construction of uncertainty sets from data, ii) develop efficient algorithms for computing near-optimal dynamic solutions for the resulting optimization problem under uncertainty and iii) disseminate the research through industry partnerships and integrating the research output into graduate curriculum and increasing the societal impact through outreach programs. 

One of the main contributions of this project is designing tractable algorithms for dynamic optimization problems under the robust uncertainty model. In particular, the research in this project shows that a static solution policy, where we compute a single (?here and now?) decision that is feasible for all future scenarios provides a near-optimal approximation for a large class of dynamic robust optimization problems. This is quite surprising and contrary to common perception of conservativeness associated with such a solution approach. Furthermore, such static solutions can be computed efficiently for a large class of problems.

Another significant contribution of this work is to greatly advance our understanding of the performance of affine policies or linear decision rules that are widely used class of policies in practice. In particular, our analysis tries to bridge a stark contrast between the worst-case tight theoretical performance bounds of affine policies and surprisingly good empirical performance. We show that affine policies are provably near-optimal for random instances under fairly general assumptions. Furthermore, affine policies provide an optimal approximation for two-stage robust optimization problems under budgeted uncertainty sets matching the hardness of approximation lower bound

Results from this project have also been instrumental in designing more general policies such as piecewise policies or threshold policies in a tractable manner. Therefore, this research is a significant step towards developing a general tractable theory for dynamic optimization has the potential of significant impact in many application areas.

In addition to advancing our theoretical understanding of dynamic optimization, the PI has strived to have a positive impact at various other levels in this project that includes: i) the dissemination of research done in this project to the real-world and ii) the training of graduate and undergraduate students in research and teaching which is an extremely important link in creating a sustainable cycle of research and its dissemination to practice, and iii) increasing the societal impact through outreach programs for local high-schools (neighbors.columbia.edu) including Society for Women in Engineering (SWE) and Harlem School Partnership (HSP) for STEM Education with particular focus on increasing the participation of underrepresented minorities. In an effort to directly disseminate the results from this research to practice, the PI actively collaborated with industry related to smart grid applications working on dynamic optimization problems arising in electricity markets due to a broader integration of highly variable renewable sources of power (such as wind and solar). The tools and insights developed in this project were crucial in addressing some of the fundamental problems in this very important application area both from an economic as well as climate point of view.
